events.name: Android Accessory Development Kit
events.description:
Want to build your own music docking station for Android, got a device if you had it connected to Android you would change the world and be a kickstarter superstar!

Join us as Pete Gordon walks us through getting up and running with the Accessory Development Kit 2011 to communicate between microcontroller embedded devices and your Android device!  We will talk Microchip PIC and Arduino; and the 2012 ADK that was just released.  But, sorry to say we didn't get our hands on one at IO--so if you were one of the lucky few that did drop us a message!

http://developer.android.com/tools/adk/index.html

http://www.engadget.com/2012/06/29/google-accessory-developer-kit/

If you can't be there in person, no worries, RSVP here, circle us on Google+ and join us through a Google Hangout on Air!

https://plus.google.com/u/3/105576655990772027346/posts

events.name: Introduction to the Go Programming Language
events.description:
Go is Google's open source programming language intended to make programmers more productive. It is designed to be expressive, concise and clean. Go compiles quickly to machine code yet has the convenience of garbage collection and the power of run-time reflection but has a simple and extensible sytax so it combines the power and efficiency of compiled languages with the flexibility and ease of use of interpreted languages. It was built from the ground up to be a concurrent language and its concurrency mechanisms make it easy to write programs that get the most out of multicore and networked machines.

Come and see Casey Borders as he introduces to the language and shows how Go simplified tasks that would be much harder is other languages.

events.name: Google Gadgets and Fun
events.description:
Going to talk about Google Contextual Gadgets in Gmail, Hangout Apps and hopefully spread some love and cheer.  Looking forward to seeing everyone.

 

https://developers.google.com/google-apps/gmail/contextual_gadgets

https://developers.google.com/gadgets/

https://developers.google.com/+/hangouts/writing

 

--Pete Gordon

events.name: No regular GDG this month--but 3d printers are cool!
events.description: We are not doing our usual Google meetup this month. But, I'll be at the Makerbot/3d printing International day tonight. Come hangout if you can! RSVP over there.... http://columbusideafo... -Pete Gordon

events.name: Holiday Social Meetup
events.description: We know that everyone is going to be busy for the Holidays so we have decided to set aside some time to get together, eat some pizza and talk Google.  So come share is some good company and holiday cheer!

events.name: Setting up an Android Development Environment
events.description: Have you ever wanted to get started with Android development?  Do you have an idea for a killer app?  Well bring in your laptop for this session and we'll get you all set up with a development environment.  We will cover installing Eclipse, the Android SDK and all of the tools you'll need to debug your code on your Android device or in the Emulator.  The first half of the meeting will be a step-by-step demonstration of how it's done and the second half will be a workshop to make sure everyone is all set up and ready to rock when they get home!

events.name: Writing your first Android App
events.description:
Be sure to bring your laptop to this meetup since we'll be writing code! We're going to walk through creating your very first Android app! This will involve creating a UI that will work across any size screen, all of the back end connections to interact with the UI via code as well as some tips and trick that we've learned along the way! The first half of the meetup will be going through the project and the second half will be a workshop to make sure that everyone leaves with a functional app!

Download and install the Android Development Tools Bundle (Eclipse and Android SDK) if you haven't done so already.

http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html

events.name: Advanced Android Development: OUYA Games
events.description:
OUYA Consoles are scheduled to be delivered this month so what better way to celebrate than to learn to program for them! Pete and Casey have had access to an OUYA for the last couple of months and are going to share their experience and tips and tricks they have learned developing games for the console!

 

Here is a map for where we are meeting:

events.name: Google TV Development with David Carver
events.description:
We are going to be meeting in the same place as last month.  For those who had trouble finding us Pete made up a map!

This month we are welcoming David Carver to talk about Google TV!  David is the developer of Serenity for Google TV a Plex Media Server client. We are going to get in depth about software design for TV (versus Tablet, Phone and other mediums); we're going to talk about the technology competition in the living room; and David Carver is going to show off Google TV and his Serenity App for Google TV and Android.  (Casey and Pete will probably talk for a minute about the OUYA launch and The GDC in March also--if anyone cares to hear--smile)

David describes himself as a Open Source, Agile Development, Eclipse and XML geek.  He's a fan of most anything doing with technology.  Home Theater, Mobile, Software Development, science fiction, gaming (both console and board games).  In the past he has run MUDs (multi-user dungeions for you old school folks, for you youngsters, they were the original MMOs.)

events.name: Google I/O Review
events.description:
We are going to be meeting in the same place as last month.  For those who had trouble finding us Pete made up a map!

Both organizers of GDG Columbus were among the lucky few to make it to Google I/O 2013! Join us for a round table discussion about what we learned from Google I/O as well as a show and tell of and Google swag that we received.

events.name: Introduction to AngularJS
events.description: Todd Barchok is the organizer of the AngularJS Meetup as well at the Game Developers Meetup Groups here in Columbus and he has agreed to give us an introduction to this interesting take on JavaScript by showing us how he used it to make a game!
events.how_to_find_us: Park in the lot on the East side of the 500 building and come in the closest door.

events.name: Introduction to HTML & CSS
events.description: Casey Borders is going to lead this beginners' guide to HTML and CSS.  If you don't know that those are, then this is the perfect MeetUp for you!  Be sure to bring your laptop since this is going to be a hands on session!
events.how_to_find_us: Park in the lot on the East side of the 500 building and come in the closest door.

events.name: Google Dev Group -- Automated Testing Android
events.description:
Automated Testing is always a challenge on projects, it has such a perceived reward, and often times a difficulty to realize those rewards. Grant James is going to share his experience with Automated Android Testing. Looking forward to hearing more about it. I think there is going to be some Cucumber, Gametel, and Robolectric. So, I'm personally hoping for a Robot that is controlled by a Game Controller that can automate Android testing and make a salad.

Hope you all can make it!

https://github.com/leandog/gametel
http://pivotal.github.io/robolectric/

events.name: Google Street View on the Oculus Rift
events.description:
Let's visit Arc de Triomphe in France and go diving with Google Street View and the Oculus Rift. We will look at the Oculus Rift working with the Google Street View API and some code that hooks up the head tracking movements (accelerometer) to street view using WebSockets. Come prepared to explore the Real World Virtually!

Be sure to note; we meet in the back of the building and there is an entrance directly into the room off the parking lot. There are some tables and chairs just outside the door.

events.name: CanAm DevFest
events.description: GDG Columbus is working with Google and other Google Developer Groups to put together a regional DevFest to be held at the Google Offices in Waterloo, Ontario.  We are still putting together the program and would love some feedback from our members about what they would like to see!  We are already planning on presentations, code labs and office hours for Google technologies like Android, Chrome, Maps, etc.  Use this MeetUp to let us know if you're interested in attending and what you would like to see!

events.name: Google Glass
events.description: Come out and join us for a Google Glass demo and discussion. Matt Schmandt has been part of the Google Glass Explorer program since Google I/O 2013 and is going to give us the good, bad, beautiful and ugly on Google Glass here in Central Ohio. Come on out on the fourth Thursday this month, and let's hangout and talk all things Google.

events.name: Google Glass 2.0 and Nexus 5 with KitKat
events.description:
Thursday, a week before Thanksgiving, we are going to share our Google Glasses v2.0 (Casey and I both just got Glass 2.0 and should have them to share the experience at the meeting).

In addition Casey has upgraded to a Nexus 5, and is going to show off and talk about the 4.4 Kitkat upgrade with all of us Android enthusiasts (even those that might also be iPhone users--like me!)

Casey and I are planning on picking up a few Jets pizzas to share, so if you can donate a few bucks that would be awesome!  Looking forward to seeing you all there.

If you haven't visited us before, be sure to look for the entrance on the back of the building connected, directly to the parking lot.  Text me if you have any problems and I'll try to respond quickly (but be forewarned I'm not great about getting my messages right away--smile).

[masked]-PETE (7383)

--Pete Gordon

events.name: Google Maps Business Photography
events.description: Trusted Google Photographer Mark Carper of See Inside Ohio (http://www.seeinsideohio.com/) is going to be showing us what's involved in making these amazing "indoor streetview" photographs for businesses.  Also be sure to check out his website for examples of the places he's photographed.
events.how_to_find_us: There is a parking lot in the back of the building with a door that will be unlocked.  If you try coming in the front doors they will be locked at this time.

events.name: Google Acquires Boston Dynamics and Nest
events.description: Google has made a few very interesting acquisitions recently. Let's discuss what that could mean for the direction of the company.
events.how_to_find_us: The front doors will be locked. Park behind the building and come in that door.

events.name: Google Glass in Society
events.description:
The front doors are going to be locked since it's after hours so park behind the building and come up to the door right by the lot.

All new technology has a learning curve both on the part of the new user and for society at large.  Big shifts in paradigm can cause some very uncomfortable situations to arise that we, as a community, have to learn to work around.  Google glass is no different.  A San Jose woman was given a ticket for wearing her Google Glass while driving.  A Columbus man was pulled out of a movie theater and questioned about his Glass.  A San Francisco woman was assaulted and robbed while wearing her glass in a bar.  There has been some pretty wide-spread concern about the ever present camera and how that plays with privacy concerns.

Join us as we talk through these issues, discuss their impact on society and discuss possible futures that will result.

events.name: Google Helpouts
events.description: Google Helpouts lets you get real-time video help from a real person!  In the spirit of Helpouts we're going to open this meeting up for people to bring in projects that they are working on and get help from other members of the GDG Columbus meetup!  If you're struggling with an Android or iOS app or if you want to start a web project and need some advice come in and we'll see if we can find someone to help!  If you have a lot of experience and want to lend a hand join up and together we and help our community!
events.how_to_find_us: The front doors will be locked because this is after hours, please park behind the building and come to the door nearest the parking lot.

events.name: Android Wear
events.description: Join us as we dive into the Android Wear SDK, Google's expansion into wearable Android devices. We will show the SDK with example apps and talk about how to implement the SDK in your own projects.  This will be followed by a lively discussion about the current limitations and the possible futures of the project!  Good Times!
events.how_to_find_us: The front doors will be locked because this is after hours, please park behind the building and come to the door nearest the parking lot.

events.name: Android Wear Hackathon
events.description:
Our last meeting showed that there was a lot of interest in Android Wear so we decided to put on an Android Wear Hackathon to see what you could come up with!  We realize that this is pretty short notice so we hope you can help us spread the word!  There will be pizza, prizes and a great group of geeks to spend the evening coding with!  Even if you don't have an app idea come on in and lend a hand to someone else or maybe find inspiration once you're here!

Before the event be sure to sign-up for the Android Wear Developer Preview and download the support library after getting accepted. It takes up 24 hours to get approved.

Sponsors:
events.how_to_find_us: The front doors will be locked because this is after hours, please park behind the building and come to the door nearest the parking lot.

events.name: Google I/O Recap and Android Wear Hackathon Winners
events.description: Let's get together and discuss all of the announcements from this year's I/O! Also we're going to give the winners of the Android Wear Hackathon a chance to show off their apps!

events.name: Code and Coffee
events.description: We're getting together with some of the members of the local Girl Develop It group to have some coffee and talk shop!

events.name: AndroidWear Development Deep Dive
events.description:
Come out with us and see what it takes to build Apps and Notifications for AndroidWear.  

We will show off the difference between AndroidWear Apps and Notifications code development, the differences in User Experience, show Custom Layouts and Voice Input, and dive deep into code and the glanceable user interface all of which makes AndroidWear unique.

As always, any problems finding us, or any questions, reach out to me.  

Pete Gordon,[masked]-PETE (7383), [masked]

events.name: Google Chat...
events.description:
Let's talk about all the stuff going on within Google; particularly the stuff that is NOT getting a lot of press. Google Domains, Anti-Aging, Quantum Chip, Google Universal Analytics (out of beta and shifting towards), AndroidOne, Project Loon, Project X (Wings/Drones), Google Fiber, Chrome Dev Editor, Chrome Cordova App, Google Sheets, Polymer vs. Angular, Sony AndroidWear Watch, Material Design and anything else that we can dig up or you want to talk about related to Google. Come on out and hangout with us for a bit and talk all things Google, Software and Development. 

I've started a list here also, if you want to see some details...  goo.gl/Fhp0Ec

Feel free to contact me with more suggestions also.

Come to the back of the building, we meet right off the parking lot in the casual lounge. Reach out anytime... [masked][masked]-PETE (7383)

events.name: Ohio Game Developer Expo
events.description:
The OGDE is the premier game developer conference in the Midwest and surrounding area. This event offers game developers, players, and fans that opportunity to network with like-minded people, and see the newest in games. Guests will have access to presentations, workshops, and events designed to build opportunities to grow the Game Development industry in the Midwest and beyond.This years event will take place on October 25th and 26th in Columbus, Ohio.

Visit https://www.ohiogamedevexpo.com to register and purchase tickets.

events.name: Ohio Game Developer Expo
events.description:
The OGDE is the premier game developer conference in the Midwest and surrounding area. This event offers game developers, players, and fans that opportunity to network with like-minded people, and see the newest in games. Guests will have access to presentations, workshops, and events designed to build opportunities to grow the Game Development industry in the Midwest and beyond.This years event will take place on October 25th and 26th in Columbus, Ohio.

Visit https://www.ohiogamedevexpo.com to register and purchase tickets.

events.name: Discuss Android 5.0
events.description: We are still working on getting a new meeting place.  We are hoping to have it nailed down for our first meeting of the new year but for now we'll make do with a Panera.  Since this is a less formal setting this is going to be a less formal meeting.  Google is in the process of pushing out Android 5.0, codename: Lollipop so let's talk about the new features!

events.name: Holiday Get Together
events.description:
Since Casey had changed jobs we have been looking for a new location to hold our meetups.  We wanted some place that had a nice room to hold meeting as well as something that was more centrally located to be more convenient.  I think we have found that place!  We are amazingly excited to announce that this meeting will be hosted by Pillar Technology in the Smith Brothers building!

This meetup should be a great way to wrap up the year!  There is no set schedule but we will be hanging out talking tech and, as always, we'll have a few cool toys to show off!  There will be food and refreshments so, please, stop by and enjoy an evening of hanging out and talking shop!

events.name: Testing with Android
events.description:
Trying to do test driven development for Android applications can be a painful process and cause an already receding hairline to accelerate. The Android Test framework is slow, and requires either an emulator or a physical device to test upon. There are other solutions like Robotium or UIAutomator but these lend themselves to writing tests that drive the UI and lean toward Integration tests. While these are necessary part of testing, they don't provide quick feed back to the developer. In this talk David Carver will discuss lessons learned from using Robolectric 2.3 and Mockito to bring some sanity to unit testing Android applications. Allowing for a true test driven development with fast test execution and fast developer feedback of failures. We will review some dos and don'ts when using Robolectric, and when Mockito may be a better fit. Examples will be shown from using these frameworks to provide unit test coverage for an Android TV application, but the same techniques can be used for any Android application.

David Carver has over 20 years in software development, ranging from the big old Mainframe to mobile applications. His primary expertise are in E-Commerce and business to business development and deployment. He is a co-creator of the XSL Tools project at eclipse, and has been a committer on several eclipse projects including Vex, XQuery Tools. He is creator of Serenity for Android a Plex Media Server client focused on the 10 foot viewing experience for Android TV, Google TV, and Amazon Fire TV devices. At the Eclipse Foundation he is a member of the Eclipse Architecture Council. He is currently working for Manifest Solutions doing Android and Eclipse development.

events.name: CBUS Javascript -- Web Components and Polymer
events.description:
Going to be talking at CBUS Javascript User Group tonight (I know completely last minute to notify everyone, sorry). If you're available come on out in a couple hours and let's talk Google's Polymer project.

Pizza arrives at 6:30p; talk starts at 7:00p.

http://www.meetup.com/techlifecolumbus/events/215546672/

--Pete Gordon
GDG Columbus

events.name: Android Udacity "Study Jam"
events.description:
Google has launch the StudyJam website. There are people across the world doing this in Feb and March. Check it out...
http://developerstudyjams.com/

There is a G+ community for all participants, that just went live. Check it out...
https://plus.google.com/u/0/b/104693551891691428892/communities/107779414017676143474/members

So, the time has arrived.  Casey and I will be facilitating seven Android Udacity "Study Jam" sessions starting in February with SWAG from Google for those that complete the full course.  That's right, you heard me correctly, SEVEN sessions over a couple months.  We are both in the process of completing the course as I type this and will be kicking off the sessions for all who are interested and ready to get involved coding Android.  It's a ton of work, and a ton of fun.

https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/StudyJam

We are still working out a lot of the details; but stay tuned and RSVP here if you are ready to dive into Android, do some serious learning, and have some fun with Android.

--Pete Gordon

events.name: Android Udacity "Study Jam" (week 2)
events.description:
Looking forward to seeing everyone again on Monday for some more jamming Android code.

It's not too late! Even if you missed the first study jam, get busy on the Udacity course:
https://www.udacity.com/course/ud853

Rocket your way through lessons one and two and show up Monday at 6pm for some group jamming of Android code.

events.name: Android Udacity "Study Jam" (week 3)
events.description:
Week 3 of the study jam... come out and jam some Android code with us. Try to have lesson 3 complete before the meetup (sorry for the last minute reminder). <smile>

Agenda:

6:00-6:10pm  Announcements (any news about Google, GDG, Android) from Pete and Casey

6:10-6:30pm  Open Question/Answer on Udacity Course  (come with your questions)

6:30-7:30pm  Coding Jam

7:30-7:50pm  Open Questions/Answers on Udacity Course

7:50-8:00pm Any additional announcements?  See you next week!

events.name: All things Google, and maybe some Polymer.
events.description:
Going to have our regularly scheduled Monthly meetup this month. Come on out and talk all things Google; and I may share the Polymer talk and demo that I did at the Javascript User Group last month (if there is interest).

https://www.polymer-project.org/

http://webcomponents.org/

events.name: Android Udacity "Study Jam" (week 4)
events.description: Lesson 4a is upon us! Had 17 people at our week 3 (lesson 3) JAM even with all the nasty weather. Come on out Monday for Lesson 4a Study Jam! So you may notice that lesson 4 is divided into a, b and c. If you can make it through lesson 4a and get into 4b that would probably be best for our jamming on Monday. Come with questions and ready to help others. Looking forward to getting together.

events.name: Android Udacity "Study Jam" (week 5)
events.description: More than half way through the Udacity course! Push through 4abc this weekend and try to get deep into 5. Let's talk about plans for Final projects this week. What kind of app do you really want to build?

events.name: Android Udacity "Study Jam" (week 6)
events.description: Just a few weeks left, until you are a Android master!  Push through lesson 5 and the Responsive Layouts, and again come prepared to discuss your final project.  Hopefully start working on your final project, if you haven't started it as of yet.  Please RSVP so we have an accurate count for food.  Thanks!

events.name: Android Udacity "Study Jam" (week 7)
events.description: How's this for last minute! Hope you all already had on your calendar our 7th study jam, which is tonight. Hopefully, you are finishing up the course blasting though lesson 5, pushing through lesson 6, and designing your final project. Please RSVP to give us a count for pizza tonight.

events.name: Some Cordova cake; Mobile Apps and Javascript
events.description:
Discussion and code on cordova and Google's chrome toolchain for building mobile apps with Internet technologies.  Come on out and be dazzled by Javascript taking over Android and iOS as we talk all things Cordova.  Please RSVP so we have an accurate count for pizza.

https://developer.chrome.com/apps/chrome_apps_on_mobile

events.name: Android Udacity "Study Jam" (week 8)
events.description:
Less than two weeks left and we are in the final stretch. We also have a big announcement coming this week for a Android Development challenge with awesome prizes so watch your inbox, tell your friends, and get ready to build sweet Android Apps.

If you are active in the Udacity Study Jams, please fill out the follow survey from google. http://goo.gl/wKVHkE

Please, please, make sure to RSVP so we get an accurate count for this coming Monday. Thanks!

events.name: Android Chops Challenge ("Study Jam" final week)
events.description:
So, we have reached the end of the "Study Jam"! Time to celebrate, but there is much more to do! Here is the announcement for the Android Chops Challenge. We are giving away AndroidWear devices and other goodies.....

The Google Developer Group (GDG) of Columbus, Ohio is sponsoring an Android Chops Challenge with over $1000 worth of prizes and the opportunity to show off your Android "chops". So, it's time to ramp up your Android Mobile app ideas and get to coding. We will be holding an informational kick-off event on March 30th at 6pm during the last Android Study Jam at Pillar Technologies' the Forge (please RSVP on meetup.com). Here's the low down. All apps must be submitted by May 1st; the winners will be showcased at the GDG Columbus May 21st event. And, we will hold a second information event, as part of our regularly scheduled April 16th meetup leading up to the May 1st submission deadline (where we will also be talking about the "Rust" programming language).

There will be two tracks of prizes, a track open to any one in the central Ohio area that wants to show off their Android Chops and build any type of "new" app for Android; and a track for those who have attended the Study Jam and whose apps meet the specifications laid out by Udacity Android Fundamentals course--(as we are coming to the end of the Udacity Android "Study Jam" 9 week series).

The prizes available for each of the two tracks are the following: 1st place is a choice of Moto 360 or Asus Zen Watch; 2nd place a Moto 360 or Asus Watch (what 1st place did not choose); 3rd and 4th place will receive a Google Chromecast device and encouragement to build something using the Google Cast API in the future.

We are thrilled to have the following amazing judges for the Android Chops Challenge submissions in May:

Alex Frommeyer, CEO of Beam Technologies
Laura Parrish, Google[masked] Student Ambassador to The Ohio State University
Joel Gerber, Founders Factory
Brenda Stier-Anstine and her team at MarketingWorks.

So don't delay get to coding now and build some amazing things on Android and start showing off your Android Chops. Register at the following link ASAP and receive later details on how to submit your app by May 1st:

http://goo.gl/xM68bR

events.name: "Rust" Programming Language
events.description:
Really excited to have Alex Burkhart coming in to give us an intro to the Rust Programming Language which has been created by the Mozilla Research.  

Come have some pizza and beer at Pillar's The Forge; and let's talk Rust.  We will also address any questions that may arise for the Android Chop Challenge.  Apps are due by May 1st; and be sure to register your app submission here...  http://goo.gl/xM68bR

http://www.rust-lang.org/

The prizes available for each of the two tracks are the following: 1st place is a choice of Moto 360 or Asus Zen Watch; 2nd place a Moto 360 or Asus Watch (what 1st place did not choose); 3rd and 4th place will receive a Google Chromecast device and encouragement to build something using the Google Cast API in the future.

We are thrilled to have the following amazing judges for the Android Chops Challenge submissions in May:

events.name: Monthly Meetup (Android Chops Winners)
events.description: Showing off the Android Apps from the Android Chops Challenge. Talking all things Google and Android. Please RSVP. Pillar will be providing eats and drinks. Thanks Pillar!

events.name: Monthly Meetup (Google IO Recap)
events.description: Google IO is running the end of May.  We'll be doing a recap of the announcements, hopefully showing off some new Google toys, and talking all things Google.

events.name: Project Fi, Polymer and Dagger Tips and Tricks
events.description:
This meeting is going to be a veritable buffet of information!  We're splitting the meeting up into three bite-sized talks.

Casey Borders is going to present Project Fi, Google's foray into becoming a cellular provider.

Pete Gordon will talk about the state of custom elements with Polymer now that it's considered production ready.

David Carver has some cool tips and tricks for how to do dependency injection with Dagger with passing Contexts all over the place.

events.name: RoboElectric, Alphabet, Nexus 2015, Physical Web, and more.
events.description:
How about this for last minute!

So it is startup week, and startup weekend coming up this weekend.  Let's talk the new Alphabet Inc "startup", Nexus 2015, Physical Web, and Roboelectric.  Come hang out and talk all things Google, Android, Chrome and now Alphabet.  We might even talk a little about startups, and Google's Launchpad initiative.

Looking forward to seeing everyone Thursday!

Pete and Casey

http://www.theverge.com/2015/8/16/9163593/lg-nexus-5-lg-smartphone-leaked-picture

events.name: Android:  Chrome Custom Tabs with Aaron Rietschlin
events.description:
It's Android time again!  

We're excited to have Aaron Rietschlin, lead Android developer at Duet Health, showing off the new Chrome Custom Tabs in Android; bring the web into your app, with the benefits of Chrome's shared state and without the user leaving your app.  Come out with all of your Android questions, and experiences and let's show the world that Columbus has Android Chops!

events.name: Android App Showcase
events.description:
Come on out and join us for Android App Showcase this Thursday.  Columbus does have some serious Android Chops and we will be showing off a few off them.  So come on out; please RSVP for pizza and beer; and let's talk all things Google and Android.

Also, wanted to make you aware of a couple local Android positions....

http://digintent.applytojob.com/apply/3Odnl6/Android-Developer-Mid-Level-And-Senior.html?source=GDG  

...from Bryan Gintz

http://www.inmobly.com/mobile-software-developer-opening/

...from Nayer Wanas

events.name: Android Game Development using OpenGL ES 2.0
events.description: Peter Hewitt will talk us through how he settled on OpenGL ES 2.0 for his game and show us how he created it from the ground up on Android. His game is available on the Google Play Store as part of the Beam Dental app. As always there will be great discussion, pizza and beer on tap! Joins us for a fun evening!

events.name: HandmadeCon
events.description:
Casey Muratori is a professional game developer with over 15 years in the industry. He has spent the last year live streaming himself for an hour a day, every weekday, developing a productional quality game completely from scratch using absolutely no libraries or frameworks. This took off beyond his wildest dreams and he's decided to try to put on a conference based on the series.

For HandmadeCon he has lined up a full day's worth of amazing speakers from the games industry and, in the spirit of Handmade Hero, he's live streaming the whole thing! Here's the schedule for the day. (All times are in EST)

1:30pm - 2:45pm
Tommy Refenes
Kicking off the conference is none other than Tommy Refenes, the sole programmer behind the massive hit Super Meat Boy. Extremely difficult platformers like this live and die by their control schemes, and Super Meat Boy stands out as a universally lauded example of how to do player controls right.
Platformer control programming is still much more art than science, so I really wanted to talk to Tommy about how he approached this classic problem, how he handled the interaction of the controls with the game physics, and what sort of tricks he employed to make Super Meat Boy feel so smooth and intuitve. From there, I’ve got a ton of other questions, ranging from how he built and maintained the art pipeline for Edmund McMillen to how he deals with the challenges of programming games entirely by himself.

2:50pm - 4:05pm
Mike Acton
Next up is Mike Acton, a programmer from the other end of the team scale spectrum. Mike leads the programmers at Insomniac, the developer famous for the Ratchet and Clank series, Resistance, Fuse, and Sunset Overdrive. As he laid out in his now-famous CPPCon keynote on data-oriented design, Mike believes in focusing on the hardware and eschewing the typical OOP design methodologies common in large-scale programming.
I’ve got a bunch of questions for Mike, but first and foremost I’ll be asking about his experiences managing large teams of programmers while still maintaining sane development practices. On Handmade Hero, I’m constantly asked whether practical programming techniques “scale”, and I can’t think of anyone better to answer this question than Mike.

4:35pm - 5:50pm
Pat Wyatt
Kicking off part two of the con is Pat Wyatt, one of the main programmers behind some of the best-known series in gaming history: Warcraft, Diablo, StarCraft, and Guild Wars. He co-founded ArenaNET, and personally designed and programmed the core networking code for the original Guild Wars launch, one of the most robust multiplayer networking launches I’ve ever seen.
On Handmade Hero, one of the most common things I get asked about that we don’t cover is network programming. If there’s one person who knows network programming for games inside and out, it’s Pat, and I have a ton of questions for him about how he approaches network architecture, both client-side and back-end.

5:55pm - 7:10pm
Jonathan Blow
Next up is Jonathan Blow, lead programmer and designer of the classic platform puzzle game Braid and the massive, highly anticipated 2016 puzzle-exploration game The Witness. Looking ahead to the complexity of his future game designs, and unsatisfied with the state of C++ as a game programming language, Jon recently undertook the design and implementation of his own brand-new programming language, in which he has already demonstrated several advanced features that make C++ look like an antiquated toy.
There’s so many things to talk about with Jon, it’s going to be hard to fit it all in, but I’ll do my best. We’ll talk about how he’s managed the complex programming necessary to bring his intricate puzzle designs to life, what spurred him to start working on his own programming language, and how he sees it changing the way he programs games in the future.

7:15pm - 8:30pm
Ron Gilbert
Bringing the conference to a close is none other than a programming hero of mine, Ron Gilbert. Quite literally the inventor of the traditional point-and-click adventure game, Ron programmed the original SCUMM scripting language and lead the LucasArts team that created what is arguably the most beloved graphical adventure of all time, The Secret of Monkey Island. Last year, after having helmed dozens of games at big studios, Ron decided to return to his roots and write a brand-new adventure game engine for a new indie adventure series, Thimbleweed Park.
When I was a kid, I played the heck out of Monkey Island (and Monkey Island 2), and as an aspiring programmer, there were so many questions I wished I could have asked Ron about how it worked. HandmadeCon is my big chance to make those wishes come true :) And it’s going to be even more illuminating now to hear about what has changed and what has stayed the same in his approach to creating an engine for the genre which he pioneered.
events.how_to_find_us: The building is down the gravel drive way just behind Technology Connection. The building has "The Mill" painted on it.

events.name: Holiday Social Gathering
events.description:
Since everyone is going to be busy with the holidays we aren't going to have a set program for this meetup. We just want to set aside some time to get together and talk tech.

You'll notice that we're going to be at a different location. Lextant was kind enough to let us hang out with them for the evening.

events.name: Android Automated Testing with Calabash
events.description: Nick Stalter is going to take us through setting up an automated testing environment and implementing the tests for Android using Calabash.

events.name: Android Development Study Jam
events.description:
Google has teamed up with Udacity to create a beginner Android development course. If you are new to programming and don’t know where to start, then this is the course for you! In this course you will learn the basics of Android and Java programming, and take the first step on your journey to becoming an Android developer!

This course is designed for students who are new to programming, and want to learn how to build Android apps. You don’t need any programming experience to take this course. If you’ve been using a smartphone to surf the web and chat with friends, then you’re our perfect target student!

Learning anything new can be tough. We will walk you through the process of making Android apps, but to get the most out of this course, you must bring your enthusiasm for learning, and budget time on your calendar to learn with us.

By the end of the course, you’ll build two simple (but powerful) apps that you can share with your friends. We also hope that you will learn enough through this course to decide how best to continue your journey as an Android app developer, if you’re interesting in pursuing such a path.

events.name: Android Development Study Jam
events.description:
Google has teamed up with Udacity to create a beginner Android development course. If you are new to programming and don’t know where to start, then this is the course for you! In this course you will learn the basics of Android and Java programming, and take the first step on your journey to becoming an Android developer!

This course is designed for students who are new to programming, and want to learn how to build Android apps. You don’t need any programming experience to take this course. If you’ve been using a smartphone to surf the web and chat with friends, then you’re our perfect target student!

Learning anything new can be tough. We will walk you through the process of making Android apps, but to get the most out of this course, you must bring your enthusiasm for learning, and budget time on your calendar to learn with us.

By the end of the course, you’ll build two simple (but powerful) apps that you can share with your friends. We also hope that you will learn enough through this course to decide how best to continue your journey as an Android app developer, if you’re interesting in pursuing such a path.

events.name: Kotlin for Android
events.description:
Kotlin is a new, open-source programming language that's being backed by JetBrains. The goal is to make a concise, safe and versatile language that interoperates seamlessly with Java. The language just hit 1.0 in February and the Kotlin team says it's ready for production use! So let's get together and see what it has to offer and how hard (or easy) it will be to develop Android apps solely in Kotlin.

You'll notice this meetup is later than our usual time. This is because we will be running our Android Study Jam this week as well. The Study Jam will be from 6:00pm - 7:30pm and the Kotlin discussion will be from 7:30pm - 9:00pm. Feel free to join us at any time though!

events.name: Android Development Study Jam
events.description:
Google has teamed up with Udacity to create a beginner Android development course. If you are new to programming and don’t know where to start, then this is the course for you! In this course you will learn the basics of Android and Java programming, and take the first step on your journey to becoming an Android developer!

events.name: Google Dev Group - Monthly
events.description: To be determined. So much always going on in the Google and Android Universe we'll think of something cool to talk about.

events.name: Google I/O Recap
events.description:
Join us to discuss all the new and exciting things announced at this year's Google I/O!

We'll begin with a Hangout that will be a presentation and Q&A about Google's new Firebase platform unveiled at Google I/O. James Tamplin, co-founder of Firebase, and Magnus Hyttsten, Firebase Developer Advocate, will share the latest and answer your questions.

How to submit questions

You can start submitting your questions now. Post them on Google+ or on Twitter using the hashtag #AskFirebaseLive.

events.name: Continuous Integration and Android with Eric Coleman
events.description: Eric Coleman is a developer at Pillar Technology and will be giving a talk on continuous integration and Android development. Please join us to learn about the benefits and methodologies related to automating build processes.

events.name: Realm Databases on Android with Eric Maxwell
events.description:
Realm Java is the easy, simple way to work with data in your apps. With an almost zero-configuration setup, reactive objects, and safe models, your apps will be faster for your users and easier for you to build. Plus Realm Java is built specifically for mobile apps, so its performance is first class. And when you need them, power‑user features, like simple migrations, built-in encryption, and more, are all there for you.

Best of all, Realm Java is written in Java, for Java, with Android at heart. Use techniques you already know, like fluent interfaces, UI adapters, and field annotations.

events.name: All things Google and Internet (Monthly Meetup)
events.description:
Greetings Google Developer fanatics!

Nothing specific on the agenda as of yet for this month (tomorrow).  I might share a little Google Speech-to-Text API experience; and maybe talk about the ML/AI API competition heating up between Google, Microsoft, and IBM (and a little Apple and HP).  But, we likely will just eat pizza, drink some beer and have an open mic to chat.

As always, we talk all things Internet, Virtual Reality, and Google related.  Don't forget November 19th University of Cincinnati with some big Google names at ohiodevfest.com!

Looking forward to hanging out with you all tomorrow.

Pete Gordon [masked]-PETE) and Casey Borders

events.name: Google Speech API (all things Cognitive and a little Machine Learning)
events.description:
Come on out for a demo, discussion, and code about the Speech API from Google.  (https://cloud.google.com/speech/)

I'll also talk briefly about other competitors (IBM Watson, Microsoft Cognitive, HP) and we'll have a small discussion on Machine Learning in general.  If you're interested in diving deep try this course from Coursera/Stanford. (https://www.coursera.org/learn/machine-learning)

Looking forward to seeing everyone in October!

If you haven't yet signed up for Ohio DevFest in Cincinnati, be sure to do so.  Jake Wharton from Square and Android fame, Shanee Nishra from Google VR Tilt Brush, and many more great speakers will be there!  https://ohiodevfest.com

-- Pete Gordon, Columbus Collaboratory Software Guy

events.name: Building Android Apps with Firebase
events.description: Building an Android application is hard. Building an Android application with a backend is even harder. Firebase is a tool that helps alleviate that. In this talk, we will talk about some of the tools offered by Firebase that can help make you build a fully functional android app, complete with a backend, push notifications, analytics and more.

events.name: Hacking the Smart Glasses
events.description: There's a hackathon for Android developers tomorrow, Hacking the Level smart glasses. They're offering $3k in cash prizes. Also, a nice pair of Nike sunglasses will go to all weekend participants. It starts at 3:30 tomorrow, but you can go after work and join up with a team. It ends on Sunday at noon with lunch, judging and prizes. All food is provided throughout the weekend. There are a few spots left. Grab tickets here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hack-the-glasses-tickets-29083424305

events.name: Ohio DevFest
events.description:
GDG Columbus is teaming up with GDG Cincinnati to put on Ohio DevFest! Ohio DevFest will be a one day developer conference with great speakers organized into multiple tracks. After a full day of the latest and greatest in the software world, join us at the after party for a chance to get to know the speakers and your fellow attendees even better!

Ticket are available at EventBrite.

You can get all the latest information at ohiodevfest.com

events.name: Columbus Tech Community Holiday Celebration
events.description:
Get your free ticket on Eventbrite!

Columbus is awesome place to be thanks to our active and passionate community. This is an invitation to all members of cbus tech, creative, and startup groups. This is the third year we've thrown a holiday celebration Instead of our usual monthly meetings, join us for food and libations. We welcome all visionaries, hustlers, and hackers. Let's get together and celebrate the holidays!
We have the leaders and members of many Ohio organizations attending.

Please welcome our returning groups:
Central Ohio Agile Association
Central Ohio Python Users Group
Code Jam Columbus
ColumbusPHP
Columbus Ruby Brigade
Columbus Startup Weekend
Columbus Web Group
Central Ohio Python Users Group
DevOps Columbus
Girl Develop It Columbus
IxDA Columbus
LOPSA Columbus
OWASP Columbus

Welcome groups joining us for the first time this year!
Cbus Product Club
Create Columbus Commission
CodePen Dayton
Columbus Code Camp
GDG Columbus
Lean Lab
Meteor Columbus
Product Hunt Columbus
ScaleTech

This year we'll have special events including live bands and from the Columbus music scene. Welcome Desert Fires and Whirlybirds!

Thanks to our sponsors for helping make this event possible!
CoverMyMeds

Because it’s the Season of Giving, we'll be announcing opportunities to donate to charities as part of our celebration in lieu of admission fees.

Sponsorship opportunities are being extended on an invitation only basis. We sold out last year and expect to do so again this year. If you plan to attend, please RSVP. If you can't attend, please cancel your registration so someone else can.

Keep an eye out on the event page for more information as it becomes available!

events.name: Let's talk AI Conversations, Assistant, Actions and Bots....
events.description:
This month we are going to talk about AI Conversations; specifically Google Actions and Google Assistant (Api.AI).  We will also spend some time on Facebook Wit.AI, IBM Conversation Watson Service, and Microsoft LUIS.

I (Pete Gordon) have been working at the Columbus Collaboratory and working with IBM Watson Services, NodeJS/NodeRed, and the tidal wave that is AI, Machine Learning, NLP, and Speech interfaces with the biggest companies collaborating in Columbus.  http://columbuscollaboratory.com/

Looking forward to seeing everyone Thursday.  Please RSVP on the GDG Meetup site.

https://developers.google.com/actions/

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9SUAuy9OJg4

https://stanfy.com/blog/advanced-natural-language-processing-tools-for-bot-makers/

events.name: Android Programming and Testing
events.description:
Java + Robolectric + Junit + NativeScript + Javascript + Other JVM languages

Basically what you need to get started, and will cover other options for programming

events.name: Secured Surfing
events.description:
Encryption, Tor, VPNs, Habits to make your digital footprints smaller, Censorship, and Net Neutrality. Designed for humans. 

In this talk, we explore your basic home network’s layout, where and how your data can be intercepted, a very brief explanation behind how encryption actually works, how Tor and VPNs can help subvert censorship and anti-net neutrality implementations, how to get up and running with Tor quickly and easily, and a few reasons on why you should actually care.

events.name: Using Realm for Data Synchronization
events.description:
When it comes to mobile development, a solid user experience is key, but as a mobile developer you’re faced with many obstacles that make this challenging including (network reliability, authentication, encryption, data serialization, data consistency, offline storage, and error handling at every level of the stack) to name a few… and somewhere in that mountain of concerns, is your business logic, the app you actually care about.

In this talk, we’ll analyze these obstacles in detail and see how the Realm Mobile Platform handles this for you, letting you focus on what makes your app unique.

You’ll also learn, through a live demo, how you can start using it in your own applications.

events.name: CBUSJS -- NodeRed, NodeJS and Flow Programming
events.description: GDG's own Pete Gordon is going to talk NodeRed, NodeJS and Flow Programming at CBUSJS, the central ohio Javascript user group in May. Come on out to the same place just the day before GDG to discuss visual flow programming goodness, and checkout nodered.org, noflo, unreal blueprints, and Ivan Sutherland's Sketchpad. It's the day before GDG so plan on two nights in a row of tech talk at the Forge with friends.

events.name: GoLang Meetup Kickoff
events.description: The Go programming language has skyrocketed in popularity since its introduction in 2012, jumping from #44 in the TIOBE Index in 2016 to #17 today. It is quickly becoming the lingua franca for cloud infrastructure with projects like Docker and Kubernetes being built upon it. We'll look into why Go is well-suited for cloud infrastructure, microservices, command-line utilities and even embedded systems, and dive into some of the design choices in the language that run counter to contemporary programming language practice.

events.name: Google I/O Recap
events.description: Google I/O is Google's annual tech conference where they make some of their biggest announcements. Join us for a discussion of the new tools and products announced this year!

events.name: TensorFlow
events.description:
An open-source software library for Machine Intelligence.

Yep, that's what TensorFlow is.

But, join us for more. Slava Nikitin and I (Pete Gordon) work at the Columbus Collaboratory where we do Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence and Analytics software projects for our seven member companies (http://columbuscollaboratory.com/Company). We primarily use R and JavaScript; and have recently done a real-time NLP Complaint Classifier in R and TensorFlow (with a little NodeJS/NodeRed sprinkled in for good measure).

https://tensorflow.rstudio.com/index.html

Python enthusiasts are also very welcomed!

We are still finalizing the talk, but it will primarily be a TensorFlow primer, demo a NLP classifier, and an open discussion about our (mostly Slava's) experience with TensorFlow.

Looking forward to seeing you in July!

events.name: Android and 360|AnDev Recap
events.description: Next month, Eric Maxwell, Peter Hewitt and Brad Hollander. will be coming to recap and share their experiences attending 360|AnDev and AnDevCon. If you couldn't make it, this is a great opportunity to see what you missed and what prominent GDE's & Google Engineers had to say about Kotlin and Architecture Components. Eric will also share where you can find all of the 360 AnDev talks.

events.name: Android ExoPlayer and a little Web Dev
events.description:
Let's talk audio/video development on Android with Dave Carver. ExoPlayer is a standard audio and video components library built on Android’s MediaCodec API.

https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/media/exoplayer.html

Also, Google announced this week a new mobile web certification they are providing. Pete Gordon will share some details. Come with questions and comments.

https://developers.google.com/training/certification/

events.name: Android and Dagger 2: The most loved/hated dependency injection framework ever
events.description:
Please note the change in date, this is the fourth Thursday rather than the third this month.  Looking forward to seeing you all for this event in October.

Dagger 2: The most loved/hated dependency injection framework ever

Dependency injection on Android is hard. There have been a number of frameworks over the years that have attempted to simplify the application of dependency injection, but none of them are as popular, or as controversial, as Dagger 2.

Dagger 2 is Google’s attempt at creating a dependency injection framework that isn’t based on reflection. Since its release, however, developers have been divided (and Google’s samples didn’t help).

If you’ve avoided Dagger 2 because it seems daunting or you have no idea how to inject a Coffee Maker, please come to this talk! I’ll attempt to demystify Dagger’s Component structures and amaze you with the power of scopes!

About Speaker

Michael Yotive is a software developer at Healthy Roster. He has been programming all around Columbus, OH for the past decade. Though primarily in the .NET world, he has spent the last couple years writing and talking about Android. When he's not programming, writing, or speaking, he can be found at a music venue or tormenting himself at a CrossFit gym.

events.name: Ohio DevFest
events.description:
It's that time again! GDG Columbus and GDG Cincinnati are putting on the second annual Ohio DevFest! Ohio DevFest will be a one day developer conference with great speakers organized into multiple tracks. After a full day of the latest and greatest in the software world, join us at the after party for a chance to get to know the speakers and your fellow attendees even better!

You can get all the latest information and buy tickets at ohiodevfest.com

*** NOTE ***

This is a ticketed event and you must purchase a ticket on Eventbrite to attend: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ohio-devfest-2017-tickets-37510713554

events.name: Columbus Tech Community Holiday Celebration 2017
events.description:
Columbus is an awesome place to be thanks to our active and passionate community. This is an invitation to all members of cbus tech, creative, and startup groups.

This is the fourth year we've thrown a holiday celebration Instead of our usual monthly meetings, join us for food and libations. The past two years we sold out, so this year we have a bigger venue and hope to have enough space for everyone. Big thanks to Hopewell for hosting us!

We welcome all visionaries, hustlers, and hackers. Let's get together and celebrate the holidays!

This event is brought to you by TechLife Columbus, Tech Community Coalition, and all your local community organizers. We have the leaders and members of over 19 Ohio organizations attending.

This is a ticketed event, so if you plan on attending, please, register on Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/columbus-tech-community-holiday-celebration-2017-tickets-38714013657

events.name: Blockchain depths and CES 2018
events.description:
Two parts and a lot of Open discussion. Let’s learn from each other.

First, Blockchain. Pete’s going to share some Blockchain knowledge touching on Bitcoin Script and Ethereum Assembly (Solidity Assembly), Virtual Machine, Web3.js, JSON RPC. Let’s talk about Cryptocurrencies running on the Internet. Come to learn, participate, and share on the depths of Blockchains, peer-to-peer networks, cryptography. Secondly, Google made a big showing with Google Assistant at CES 2018. The battle between Alexa and Assistant has been heating. Let’s chat about what was announced. Some recaps from Intel, Samsung, Nvidia, and others. What did you hear about that was interesting? What did you wish you would have heard about that you didn’t.

Looking forward to seeing you all Thursday!

events.name: Introduction to Virtual Reality Development
events.description:
• What we'll do
We're going to show you how to get up and running with VR development using Google's Daydream VR library and Unity.

• What to bring
You should bring a laptop with Unity installed and it would be best if you could bring a Daydream compatible phone (listed below) but that is not necessary.

Google Pixel and Pixel 2
Samsung Note8, Galaxy S8 and S8+
ASUS ZenFone AR
LG V30
Motorola Moto Z, Moto Z Force and Moto Z 2 Force
ZTE Axon 7
Huawei Mate 9 Pro and Porsche Design Mate 9

!! Important to know !!

Before you come make sure your system is configured for Android development using the Android SDK/NDK Setup Guide.
https://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/android-sdksetup.html

Download and install Unity from the Unity Website. **It’s important to make sure that you check the box next to Android Build Support during install**
https://unity3d.com/get-unity/download

Download the GoogleVR for Unity package from the GoogleVR GitHub page.
https://github.com/googlevr/gvr-unity-sdk/releases

This will make sure that everyone is ready to get started since downloading these things can take quite a bit of time.

events.name: Learn about Firebase
events.description:
• What we'll do
This month Bryan Gintz is going to show us how Firebase makes building Android apps easier and more efficient.

• What to bring

• Important to know

events.name: Learn about Google's Vision APIs
events.description:
• What we'll do
Patrick Read is going to show us how he uses Google's Vision APIs to digitize documents at a local startup.

• What to bring

• Important to know

events.name: Google I/O Recap with CBUS Kotlin
events.description: Google I/O is Google's annual tech conference where they show the world what's going down the pipe and teach developers how to use their new technology. This year GDG Columbus and CBUS Kotlin will have people at the conference gathering first hand accounts of everything that goes on and we'll bring the news back to share with you!

events.name: Flutter
events.description: Flutter is Google’s mobile app SDK for crafting high-quality native interfaces on iOS and Android in record time. Flutter works with existing code, is used by developers and organizations around the world, and is free and open source. There are bound to be a ton of very exciting Flutter announcements at Google I/O, so come and see what's new and learn to make a cross-platform, native mobile app with Flutter.

events.name: Server Side Kotlin
events.description:
Kotlin isn't just for Android development! It's a great new language that can be used anywhere you would use Java! So come listen to Micheal Clark tell us what his team went through to evaluate the language, tooling and company culture before using Kotlin with Spring in their back-end.

* UPDATE *
We have just been informed tha, effective immediately all MeetUp attendees must park in the parking lot behind the building and not in the numbered spots in the front. The front lot is reserved for the Juniper Rooftop Bar. We have been told by Capitol that if they see someone parked in the front and they are not attending the Rooftop bar they will be towed at the owners expense.

events.name: Actions on Google, DialogFlow and Puppeteer
events.description:
This month Pete Gordon is going to show us how to harness the power of Google using our voice and how to scrape the Internet with Chrome! He has been working on an app for the Google Assistant to be able to get updates on his children's grades and he's going to walk us through how that works and how he made it.

https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer

https://developers.google.com/actions/
events.how_to_find_us: Please remember to park in the lot behind the building.

events.name: Google Cloud -- Machine Learning for Everyone
events.description:
RSVP here... https://www.meetup.com/columbus-gcp/events/254069164/

Google Cloud Meetup and Onix are hosting this meetup at The Kitchen.

Machine Learning isn’t just for data scientists these days. It’s being democratized for developers, data analysts and all technical roles in the Enterprise.

What does that mean exactly? Thanks to new tools, it’s increasingly possible to get started with machine learning and integrate it into your organization.

Join Google Cloud and Onix at the next Columbus Google Cloud Meetup.

Enjoy great food and drink, and even better company, while you learn first hand about the latest developments in machine learning for the tech masses. See demos of the latest in Google Cloud technology including Machine Learning with AutoML.

events.name: Flutter
events.description: We are extremely exciting to be welcoming Andrew Brogdon (@RedBrogdon) from the Flutter team! He's going to take us on a deeper dive of the Flutter widget system!
events.how_to_find_us: Please remember to park in the lot behind the building.

events.name: Ohio DevFest 2018
events.description: Joins us for another amazing Ohio DevFest! Tickets are available from http://ohiodevfest.com. This year is going to be even bigger and better than last year! We're going to have 24 sessions spread across 4 tracks and we expect 250 attendees! So be sure to get your tickets soon. Early bird pricing ends on September 7th.

events.name: Flutter Study Jam  (Week 1 of 3)
events.description:
Kicking off a three week Flutter study jam. Come out and go deep into Flutter with us.

If you didn't get to see Andrew Brogdon speak in September about getting comfortable with Flutter. Check out the video. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U_1QsGC_BQo
events.how_to_find_us: Park in the visitor parking spots on the south east corner of the building; go to the side door to be let into the building.  If there are no visitor parking; parking anywhere and come inside to get a parking pass.

events.name: Flutter Study Jam  (Week 2 of 3)
events.description: Kicking off a three week Flutter study jam. Come out and go deep into Flutter with us.
events.how_to_find_us: Park in the visitor parking spots on the south east corner of the building; go to the side door to be let into the building.  If there are no visitor parking; parking anywhere and come inside to get a parking pass.

events.name: Flutter Study Jam  (Week 3 of 3)
events.description: Kicking off a three week Flutter study jam. Come out and go deep into Flutter with us.
events.how_to_find_us: Park in the visitor parking spots on the south east corner of the building; go to the side door to be let into the building.  If there are no visitor parking; parking anywhere and come inside to get a parking pass.

events.name: Flutter Live Event
events.description:
We are going to hangout and watch the Flutter Live Event at the Columbus Collaboratory over lunch. Come join us.

https://developers.google.com/events/flutter-live/

events.name: Tech Community Holiday Party
events.description:
Come celebrate the holidays with us! Columbus technology community is growing and we are thrilled to be involved with it.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/columbus-tech-community-holiday-celebration-2018-tickets-52241840752

Columbus is an awesome place to be thanks to our active and passionate community. This is an invitation to all members of cbus tech, creative, and startup groups -- the visionaries, hustlers, and hackers who are building a better Columbus.

This is the fifth year we've thrown a holiday celebration Instead of our usual monthly meetings, join us for food and libations. The past four years we sold out, and we expect the same this year. Big thanks to Hopewell for hosting us!

events.name: Google Assistant Trivia Game
events.description:
Learn how to create a google voice app to make a trivia game.
Create a spreadsheet of questions and answers for a trivia game in advance.
You will build ithe trivia game and publish it in the meetup group class.

This is a hands on workshop

Please make sure you have a gmail account and bring

- your computer
- headphones
- smart phone Android or iphone with google assistant installed on it

Since this is hosted on google server, the app is created using google
actions on this console

https://console.actions.google.com

https://developers.google.com/actions/extending-the-assistant

https://developers.google.com/actions/templates/trivia

https://developers.google.com/actions/templates/flash-cards
events.how_to_find_us: Please remember to park behind the building!

events.name: I’m loving Google Cloud Functions and GSuite
events.description: Pete Gordon is going to show why Google Cloud Functions are going to change the way he develops software forever. He just deployed a significant production application built almost entirely with s few Cloud Functions. He is also going to demonstrate the power of GSuite Sheets and App Scripts and how they can be integrated with Cloud Functions. Come for a deep dive into the Cloud and a ton of JavaScript!
events.how_to_find_us: Don’t forget to park on the north side (the rear) of the building

events.name: From Hackathon to Startup
events.description:
Angela Rucci is going to talk about her experience winning the hackathon “Hack OHI/O” and turning the winning project into her own company, Tego. Tego’s product is a mobile application of the same name which focuses on enhancing user’s safety by alerting contacts automatically when they have reached their destination.

Come by to learn about the tools and techniques the Tego team used to make this application possible - including Swift, Laravel, Node (using TypeScript), Amazon's web services, and Google Maps, Google Places, and Google Distance Matrix APIs.

The Tego iOS application went live recently and the Android application is slated to release in August 2019.

https://www.tego.tech/about/
events.how_to_find_us: Please remember to park in the lot behind the building. Enter through the door to Juniper and turn right to find us!

events.name: Google Next'19 Rewind
events.description:
Join us as we rewind and then step through the announcements at Google Next'19! We'll explain which announcements generated the most buzz and why. Then we'll take a deep-dive into the speaker's personal favorites: BigQuery, AutoML, and Datastudio. Learn how these tools can help you help your company grow in the cloud.

Be sure to park in back; on the north side of the building.

events.name: I/O Extended 2019 Columbus (alternate time/location!)
events.description:
Hey all

This month the GDG Columbus and GDG Android Columbus groups are joining forces to recap Google I/O.

If you haven’t heard of it, Google I/O is the biggest conference of the year for Google, showcasing all of the exciting new technology and innovations that Google has been working on for the past year.

This year we learned about how Google Lens technology is helping people who can’t read or write communicate with the world, advances in Machine Learning (ML) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) to classify objects in real time, and ways in which AI is being used to help diagnose cancer patients earlier in the process.

We also learned about several new advancements in the Android and Flutter space, including Flutter for the web and a new way to build reactive UI with Jetpack Compose.

We hope you’ll join us at Root on 5/28 for a recap and round table discussion of I/O 2019.

Thanks

(GDG x GDG Android) Columbus Teams!

Extra Venue Notes:

Root is located at 80 E Rich St. (floor 4). If you park in the garage across the street (55 E Rich St.), Root can validate your parking for you. You can walk across the sky bridge on the 2nd floor of the garage or enter Root's building from the ground entrance off Rich St. The elevator on the left labeled "Work" will allow you to go up to floor 4. Once on the 4th floor, a Root representative will be there to guide you to where the meet-up is taking place.
events.how_to_find_us: Root is located at 80 E Rich St. (floor 4). If you park in the garage across the street (55 E Rich St.), Root will validate parking. Use the sky bridge on the 2nd floor of the garage or enter Root's building from the ground entrance on Rich St.

events.name: Hangouts and New Place
events.description:
Hey All! Hope you all are available Thursday. We've got a new address venue (711 N. High St) but still with Pilar/Accenture and still called The Forge. We are going to celebrate with some pizza as usual and talk all things Google related. This is going to be more a social casual event, but please come with any Google comments, questions, and rumors. We may talk a little about Puppeteer RPA buzz, Google Vision API and competitors AWS Textract, Ohio DevFest is in Columbus this coming November, and anything else we can think of Google related. Please note the new venue:

https://www.711nhigh.com/about

First thing to note, there is valet parking; so just pull up on that side of 711 N. High Street, and tell the valet you are going to the Forge for an event.

They will give you a ticket. We will have stickers for parking to put on that ticket.

It is on the 9th floor, in the event space, and when you walk out of the elevator look for the glass door the other way will be a moss wall and entry for the rooftop bar (so first come to our glass doors--smile).

Jim, Jason and I are looking forward to seeing you all there!

If you have any questions, issues or anything reach out to me.

Pete Gordon
[masked]
[masked]-PETE (7383)

upcoming.name: Intelligent UI Automation with Chrome Puppeteer
upcoming.description:
Come out this month to our new Pillar Forge location at the beautiful new Short North building on High St. Pete's going to be demoing Google Chrome Puppeteer and talking all things UI Automation (RPA). He's been doing it for awhile and going to share what he has learned, including some info about UiPath and others that are doing windows UI Automation (not just browser automation like Puppeteer) Looking forward to seeing you.

Valet parking will be credited by Pillar, so use the convenience. Come for some pizza and drinks and some geeking out.

answers.question: What Google technologies do you currently use?
answers.answer: Android, Google Apps (with scripts, sometimes), Google Maps

answers.question: What Google technologies would you like to learn more about?
answers.answer: Android, Google TV, all things Google--Dart maybe, but not Go!  <smile>

group_profile.intro: Hello! I'm a developer in Columbus writing Android and iOS applications.
